Posts.Content: Hello, I was in two minds about blogging as I'm a private person and didn't want to broadcast my thoughts, feelings, experiences etc. The reason why I chose to blog in the end was mainly to be able to share what was going on at any point in time with family and close friends who are all outside of the UK in different countries. I think it helped them stay close and they felt reassured that they knew what was going on. For me, it turned out to be really cathartic. It also helped me keep track of events and conversations. It all happened a year ago and I would probably struggle toÂ  remember how I reached certain decisions without the blog and being able to read up on things. One last reason for blogging, was that I found reading other people's blogs helpful, a little like this forum is helpful because you read, share and connect with people going through similar experiences. So I thought maybe one day someone might come across a few things I've written and find them helpful too.
Posts.Title: Blogging

Posts.Content: I also reckon it was probably nerves more than the cold cap itself. I would say persevere with it! I had more nausea as time went on and felt that I almost felt a little nauseous before I even stepped into the clinic. Try and find some soothing music and imagine a hot summer's day on the beach to take your mind off the cold/ pain from the cap for the first few minutes. Maybe also see if they can give you something that calms you a little, something they had suggested to me, prior to the treatment. x
Posts.Title: Sickness with cold cap

Posts.Content: I also reckon it was probably nerves more than the cold cap itself. I would say persevere with it! I had more nausea as time went on and felt that I almost felt a little nauseous before I even stepped into the clinic. Try and find some soothing music and imagine a hot summer's day on the beach to take your mind off the cold/ pain from the cap for the first few minutes. Maybe also see if they can give you something that calms you a little, something they had suggested to me, prior to the treatment. x
Posts.Title: Sickness with cold cap

Posts.Content: Hi there, I also had some cording from my under arm all the way to my elbow. It took a good few weeks to get rid off but I found that massaging the area definitely helped make it feel less tight and I was able to 'crcack it' in certain places where more pressure wasn't a problem. I was also offered physio therapy which really helped as it's much easier for someone else to massage the area. Maybe you could look into that?
Posts.Title: Cording (AWS)

Posts.Content: Hello, I was diagnosed with invasive ductal breast cancer a couple of weeks and since it had also gone to two lymph nodes and due to the size, I had been strongly recommended to have a reconstructive mastectomy. I have since had this and I'm recovering well at home, ahead of what looks like chemo in three weeks' time. I'm keen to find out if there are any support groups or threads for people following this path of treatment (e.g. surgery, then chemo) and any tips on coping (acupuncture etc.). Since embarking on this new journey, there seems to be a jungle of information out there on diet advice and other tips to support healing/ health during this time. I find the conflicting advice on diet particularly confusing. Information overload! Hoping to connect with people on here and share, chat, understand, learn. Funda
Posts.Title: New to this - saying hello and looking to connect

Posts.Content: Hi Fiona, Lovely to hear from you. Let's definitely share our experiences and any useful tips/ info. I was told I have three weeks until they'd like to start with the first chemo. Still waiting for the full biopsy which will come next week as my op was only last Wednesday. I also have been to see a nutritionist and naturalist who specialises in diets for people affected by cancer, though a lot of the stuff was pretty radical. Food for thought. A couple of friends of mine who went through similar experiences a few years ago, said that having acupuncture straight after chemo really helped with nausea and other side effects. I'll definitely consider that, you might want to look into that too. Let's stay in touch! Funda
Posts.Title: New to this - saying hello and looking to connect

Posts.Content: Hey Dreamthief, thank you for your kind words. I haven't had my post op pathology report yet. All I know is that it's an invasive ductal with two nodes affected and it's estrogen receptive - not sure about HER2 or other aspects yet but will find out more next week. I have already seen an oncologist as this was recommended to me a week ago. She didn't tell me exactly which drugs they'll be using during chemo but I'll check out the clubs around this for any support once the time comes. With regards to the diet, I think I'm taking everyone's advice on 'each day at a time'. I eat healthily anyway, so for now will just add more greens to it and cut out unnecessary sugars. Speak soon, Funda
Posts.Title: New to this - saying hello and looking to connect

Posts.Content: Hi JediKnight, thank you for sharing! I'll look into the chemo club as this part of the journey is one I'm concerned about. It's very comforting to hear you say that whilst horrible, it is do-able. I like do-able! Speak soon, Funda :)
Posts.Title: New to this - saying hello and looking to connect

Posts.Content: Hi Helen, Thank you. I guess you're right - it is still all a bit early so I'll properly look at diet once I'm further down the journey. Baby steps for now! Funda
Posts.Title: New to this - saying hello and looking to connect

Posts.Content: I had a mastectomy last Wednesday and happened to come across VD's video blog on the BBC website a day before. It brought up mixed feelings in me. A part of me wanted to believe her so much that this is all 'not a big deal' but as I watched it a few times, I also realised that she must have been pretty 'high' on painkillers, especially during the first video post-op. I think the intention was probably good but the outcome was rather 'dismissive' of the procedure. As a lot of people said on here, no person or situation is the same and I agree that she probably talked too soon. I'm happy for her that it was all so easy in her case.. I feel lucky that for me the actual surgery and post-surgery hasn't caused unbearable physical pain or any complications. But I wouldn't dream of bragging about it in the way she did. I think her tone just wasn't right and skewed the whole effort behind what was meant to be a positive, encouraging piece.
Posts.Title: Anybody else been Victoria Derbyshired????????

Posts.Content: Just watched it too and I'm glad she's sharing her experiences. After all, this is what we are doing on here too? I wish her all the very best and I think it's a brave thing to do!
Posts.Title: Anybody else been Victoria Derbyshired????????

Posts.Content: Hi Ann, Actually, my hair is still falling out every day - few strands every day. I'm hoping that it will stop within the next week or so? Did the cold cap work for you then? I was told that the drugs mostly leave your system 2-3 weeks after infusion so I'm hoping hair will stop falling a couple of weeks after that. My last session was two weeks ago x
Posts.Title: COLD CAP OR NO COLD CAP?

Posts.Content: Hi Mand, I would say give it a go. If you find it unbearable you can always just take it off. I completed four cycles of EC a couple of weeks ago and used the cold cap for each session. Yes, the first 10-15 minutes are painful (and got progressively more painful as my hair thinned over the weeks) but if you can stand it for the first few minutes, you start to get used to it and barely feel it after a while. I didn't get any headaches from it but probably felt woozy and had cold feet, cold nose, hands etc. but that generally passed overnight. Everyone's different of course but for me I have managed to keep hold of a lot of hair - it has definitely thinned but I didn't lose all of it and haven't needed to wear a wig/ scarf. I would also recommend you get a silk pillowcase as it reduces the friction at night. Basically, whatever you can do to be gentle to your hair/scalp. Hope it all goes well! Funda x
Posts.Title: COLD CAP OR NO COLD CAP?

Posts.Content: Hi all, Wondered if anyone had a similar experience? It's day 10 of Tamoxifen and so far the main thing I've noticed is feeling a bit foggy. It seems I have difficulty remembering conversations from 2-3 days ago and find it hard to think clearly and articulate myself clearly, especially when I'm on the phone to people. Is this a known SE? Thinking I should maybe take the tablet last thing at night rather than after breakfast to at least sleep some of this fog off?
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen - brain fog

Posts.Content: Thank you- Will see how things develop!Â
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen - brain fog

Posts.Content: I also had cording and it kept coming back every few weeks. Physio really helped to literally massage it away. Swimming and Yoga also helped as well as any other stretching exercises. My physio told me to take painkillers and then really massage the area to try and 'crack' bits of it by myself. This also worked. I opted for no painkillers but kept pushing along the cord to loosen it and eventually make it go away. I would definitely recommend physio!
Posts.Title: How do I get rid of cording?

Posts.Content: Hi, I've also been cold capping. I would say definitely try it and just like Anne said, make sure your hair is completely wet with lots of hair conditioner on before the cap comes on. Some people also say it helps to take a paracetamol an hour beforehand. Remember that feeling when you're a child and you bite into an ice cream too quickly? That's how it felt for me during the first 10 minutes each time but you then get used to it. In my case, the cap came on around 45 minutes before the injections/ infusions and had to stay on another two hours after. I found it quite manageable the first time round but as my hair started thinning, it felt colder and more uncomfortable each time. It has, however, worked for me. Hair loss did start week 2 after the first treatment and a few strands of hair have been coming out every day since which means my hair has thinned quite a lot but not disappeared completely yet. I have one more treatment to go so I'm hopeful it stays that way. Make sure it's very tight especially around the top of your head and imagine a hot summer's day by the sea with the sun beating down on you when the cap is put on your head. Good luck and I'd say it's definitely worth trying!
Posts.Title: FEC-T and Cold Cap

Posts.Content: Hi all, Any tips for reducing hot flushes during the night? They seem to be chemo induced (I'm 8 weeks post last chemo) according to the docs and with the prospect of starting Tamoxifen in the next 1-2 weeks, I'm concerned it's only going to get worse? At the moment I seem to be waking up every hour with a hot flush which of course is leading to very disturbed sleep. I also have the occasional one during the day. I've been to a herbalist who has given me a tincture but this hasn't helped yet. I'm also having weekly acupuncture but seems that that's not kicking it either. Any tips? Thank you!
Posts.Title: Remedies for chemo induced hot flushes

Posts.Content: Thank you for the replies. I have tried the chillow pillow but it hasn't worked for me yet. Seem to get the hot flushes during the day sometimes too. Starting tamoxifen in a couple of days so will see how that goes! Happy almost-weekend!
Posts.Title: Remedies for chemo induced hot flushes

Posts.Content: Beautiful words, thank you for sharing them. I can relate to a lot of what you wrote! xx
Posts.Title: Farewell to Chemo!

Posts.Content: I would just ask your GP for a free blood test to see if you're lacking any vitamins or other essential things like magnesium or iron. I think it's a generic test they offer, not sure of any name. If you want to look up the lady I spoke to re: nutrition/ integrative medicine (I never remember the right labels), maybe have a look at Jo Gamble, based in Coventry but consults over the phone
Posts.Title: Vitamin supplements & diet advice ?

Posts.Content: Hi Isingbass, Confused.com probably summed it up for me a while ago too. I started with an extreme of cutting out dairy, sugars (fruit sugar included), meats etc and while I felt good, I lost weight and felt very restricted as to what I could eat. At the time I had consulted a nutritionist who basically prescribed this strict plan. Now, post chemo, I am sticking to some aspects of that original plan by cutting out refined sugars, processed food and dairy where I can. Dairy mainly because of the growth hormones it has, cow dairy that is. Goat and sheep milk doesn't contain the same levels. My cells were hormone receptive so that's part of the logic behind the dairy. I have since also learnt and with the help of a different nutritionist and functional medic who does Skype consultations, that a blanket approach is probably not the way to go. As with chemo reactions, cancer cells etc no body is the same and so finding out what your measures are in terms of vitamins, minerals etc which you can get done by your GP (blood test) is a good start. There are also other tests that look at vitamin D, magnesium etc I'm currently waiting to get my results so that I can decide on supplements, which supplements and what I need more or less of etc... For me this approach makes most sense as otherwise I feel pulled in too many directions.
Posts.Title: Vitamin supplements & diet advice ?

Posts.Content: Hi all, Wondered what your experience is with hair post-chemo? How long after chemo does hair growth start again? And once hair starts growing, have you noticed that it grows slower?Â
Posts.Title: Question about hair growth

Posts.Content: Hi Fiona, You were one of the first people I exchanged messages with on here and reaching out to someone for a few minutes at that point in time made such a difference. I think your treatments were slightly ahead of mine and yours and other people's posts offered me much encouragement. I'm now 9 weeks post last chemo and two days into tamoxifen. I too thought I was going to feel amazing (emotionally) after the chemo but realised I had been so focused on getting through it well physically that I hadn't allowed myself any downs, never mind ups and downs. Since then I feel like I'm on a smaller rollercoaster of emotions as I process everything that has happened to date. And I guess it takes time for all of us and patience. Baby steps. Allowing myself to be upset at what seems random times during the day is the hardest bit but I'm getting there.Â  Wishing you all the best for the next phase xx
Posts.Title: A bit of a ramble....and a thank you!

Posts.Content: Hi Dolina, I had a mastectomy in November last year, chemo from January-March and went through all of it staying strong and positive. About a month after, it all went crashing down and I'm still very emotional, up and down every day and can't shake the thoughts around cancer, recurrence, the whole experience really. I'm trying to be patient and hoping that time will soften things and allow me to feel less anxious and more confident and 'light'. I think maybe allow yourself to feel certain feelings and let yourself experience certain things before you get to a place of peacefulness. At least that's what I'm trying to do for myself and what others who have gone through similar experiences are doing too x
Posts.Title: Now the treatment is over

Posts.Content: Hi Silvercloud, I echo a lot of the comments made on here. It needs to feel right for you - whatever the decision. I was very against chemo and just couldn't get my head around it at all. The percentage benefits the oncologist had outlined were 12% I think and even though that sounds like a lot to many people, at the time it sounded too low for me. I did the endopredict test, hoping it would give some clarity but it came back as medium risk. My oncologist who isn't very aggressive said that she would recommend chemo but would support me whatever the decision I make. After many days and weeks of deliberation, I decided to have four rounds of EC. As many have said here, it's doable - draining, physically straining but doable. I was so frightened and imagined the absolute worst in terms of side effects and changes to my body. I'm now 8 weeks post treatment, about to start Tamoxifen. A part of me wonders what I would be like today if I hadn't opted for chemo but I think a bigger part of me is glad to have gone with the recommendation and to have this behind me. Of course, being adjuvant, there's no way of saying: great, it really worked. But I think overall I feel more at peace that I opted for this. Having said that, if my gut instinct had been strong enough a few weeks ago, I think I would have decided against it. Whatever you decide, if it feels right to you, then it's right. Funda xx
Posts.Title: Making the right decision

Posts.Content: Hello, Ouch, that sounds painful. I haven't had any tooth related issues but have noticed significant staining around my teeth. Don't know whether to put this down to the drugs or down to all the juicing or a combination of both but definitely different to how things were before. I also had a couple of fillings done after EC number 2 and it has taken a while for my teeth to settle as the fillings were originally too high so whenever I was grinding my teeth at night or chewing, they would hit down too hard. The dentist said it takes quite a while for teeth to settle afterwards - I imagine that if you bite down hard or grind together, it'll be a similar thing? If your teeth don't hurt constantly but only when you bite down, it might just settle without a dentist's visit?
Posts.Title: Teeth!

Posts.Content: Hi all, I completed four rounds of EC chemo 5 weeks ago. About four weeks after the last treatment, I started getting really restless at night and not sleeping well. Basically I wake up feeling hot, sweating around my forehead and chest, then after a few minutes of cooling down, I'm able to get back to sleep until a short while later and the whole thing repeats itself. I know that chemo can induce early menopause but I still have my periods (last one was too early but still very much there) and I don't have any hot flushes during the day. Wondered if this is maybe my body trying to get rid off toxins or is related to the drugs etc.?Â  Wondered if any of you had a similar experience you could share? Thank you, Funda
Posts.Title: Feeling hot and cold at night

Posts.Content: Thank you all for your replies and it's comforting that some people have experienced this too. I was starting to worry that it might be something more sinister maybe... I found it odd that it only started after the chemo and I haven't even started taking the hormone tablets yet. I'm 41 and hoping this isn't an onset of early menopause. I guess we will see!
Posts.Title: Feeling hot and cold at night

Posts.Content: Hi little wren, Definitely keeping busy is a good thing and I agree that waiting is very tough. Make sure, as someone said, to bring someone with you when you go and get the results. If you can't, then definitely record the conversation. I feel that whenever I was nervous in those meetings, I forgot half of what was said if it wasn't for the recording. Also, if you have any questions about anything, write them down beforehand, it helped me. Wishing you all the best, Funda
Posts.Title: Waiting for diagnosis

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, I have #5 this afternoon...SO looking forward to the weekend and a break from the deep inspiration breath-hold. Also no SE yet - hope everyone is having a good friday so far! xx
Posts.Title: â¢â¢â¢ June 2018 Radiotherapy Club â¢â¢â¢

Posts.Content: Thank you both for your responses. Yes, drinking more water than I’ve ever done before so here’s hoping it clears soon!Â
Posts.Title: â¢â¢â¢ June 2018 Radiotherapy Club â¢â¢â¢

Posts.Content: Hi all, I finished Radiotherapy last week, completing 15 days of it. My skin looked totally normal by the end and no other side effects. Then, after a couple of days, I noticed some redness towards the top part of my chest and little bumps - similar to those some might get with a sun allergy. They did say that the effects may only show on the skin 1-2 weeks later but then ease up a week after that. I was given ‘double cream’ to moisturise with and have religiously been applying it twice a day. It is beginning to feel quite sticky though...Â  Question: is it okay to use 100% aloe Vera to maybe ease the heat sensation and itchiness? In general, can I now use other moisturisers now that RT is over? And on holidays, I know sun block is a must - again, I assume I can use any brand? Thanks for any guidance
Posts.Title: â¢â¢â¢ June 2018 Radiotherapy Club â¢â¢â¢

Posts.Content: Thanks for all the replies. Have my follow-up appointment next Monday and will then decide which one to go with. As far as I can see there isn't much difference between AC and EC (or FEC) and hair loss I assume comes with both options.
Posts.Title: Different chemo regime options - any advice?

Posts.Content: Following another consultation it seems that the way to go now is either 12 weeks (4x 3 weeks) of AC or EC or a course of 12 (weekly) Taxol. Only thing I noticed is that Taxol may cause neuropathy - anyone had any experience of this? Thanks again for all the support xx
Posts.Title: Different chemo regime options - any advice?

Posts.Content: Hello, I had my test results of the endopredict (similar to oncotype) back and they've put me in the 'medium risk' category which means chemo is recommended. I was hoping to fall into the low risk category but I'm now slowly getting used to the idea of the imminent chemo. My oncologist said we would ideally start this side of Christmas and she has drawn up three different regimes: 1) FEC-T which is around 18 weeks 2) ACT (?) - around 16 weeks 3) Another regime (couldn't quite confirm which drugs) which is a lower dose and runs 4x 3weekly and then weekly for 12 weeks with a total of 24 weeks Has anyone else ever consider a lower dose, longer term chemo or was given these options? I find it hard to make a decision on having a shorter cycle with possibly more side effects or a longer cycle with potentially less side effects, though who knows as we can't predict the side effects. A part of me is tempted to get it over and done with while another thinks it might be less tough on a longer term, lower dose? Thanks for any feedback, Funda
Posts.Title: Different chemo regime options - any advice?

Posts.Content: Hi all, Wondered what book recommendations you may have - maybe something you read when first diagnosed or during treatment or something that was eye opening or helped you through? Keen to add some to my collection. For me, I particularly found 'the cancer whisperer', 'radical remissions' and '50 critical cancer answers' eye opening and moving. Thanks in advance for any recommendations!
Posts.Title: Books you recommend

Posts.Content: Hi Cartwheels, I had four sessions of EC in total and I cold capped throughout. The first 1-2 were kind of okay but the third and fourth one were really tough as I had started to lose some hair and so everything seems just that much colder during those two sessions. I almost gave up after the third but glad I persevered. I managed to keep enough hair (and my hair was always curly) not to wear a wig. If you can find a way to distract yourself or even watch video of hot places, maybe some beach / travel clips during the first 10-15 minutes, then I'd say try and go for it one more time. x
Posts.Title: Cold cap advice please

Posts.Content: Hi J, I relate to everything you're saying. I was at a seminar the other day and the presenter used a great analogy for the way I've been feeling. She said it's like being shipwrecked. You were on the boat, sailing along, had all the necessary maps to navigate, navigate high waves, a bit of wind, rain etc. but suddenly a massive storm took you off course and battered you around. You made it back to safe land and everyone cheered on shore, happy that all is okay. But you can't cheer along because you feel stranded, battered and bruised. For me, this was spot on but I guess we will all get back on that boat again and start sailing, just a little differently maybe or more mindfully. The hard part for me, is that I'm impatient and I just want things to be okay again but deep down I know that grief can't be rushed and I guess in some way what we're feeling is grief. Making plans and having things to look forward to definitely helps I found. Have a great time in Amsterdam! Funda xx
Posts.Title: Falling apart now it's over

Posts.Content: Hi Maria, I also started to write my journey down from the moment of diagnosis, through surgery, chemo and I still post some updates today. For me, it's been really important to keep track of conversations, how and why I made the decisions I made and all the things that happened during the early stages of diagnosis. I think it also made me reflect on things and cope better. As my family lives abroad, I wanted them to always know what was going on so I decided to capture everything on a blog rather than a physical diary. It was also a good way for me to understand myself and helped me not internalise too much but instead get thing off my chest. x
Posts.Title: Keep a diary
